item.title: Cyborgs & hyperloops: The wait continues
item.description: The first flying car was approved by regulators in 1956, but here we are, still stuck on the road. Hyperloops require route-length concrete tubes propped up on towers in the sky – as technically infeasible as the hovering trains once imagined too. Impressive as today’s AI applications are, we don’t have artificial general intelligence, the ability to make a machine think.

item.title: Hyundai Motor unveils new hydrogen-based EV concept
item.description: Hyundai Motor on Thursday unveiled the concept of its upcoming passenger hydrogen fuel cell electric vehicle (FCEV) named Initium that comes with an extended driving range and ample hydrogen fuel storage capacity.

item.title: European car safety agency snubs BYD's Atto 3 driver assistance system
item.description: The model scored zero on driver monitoring features and performed poorly in preventing undertaking at speeds over 90 kilometres per hour (56 miles per hour), among other shortcomings, according to the Oct. 23 report from the European New Car Assessment Programme (Euro NCAP).

item.title: India's EV pioneer Maini Group ventures into autonomous tech with SiMa.ai partnership
item.description: Maini Group, known for launching India’s first EV in the 1990s, has long been committed to electrifying in-plant machinery, particularly within the Class 3 segment of the material handling industry.

item.title: Mexico warns US ban on Chinese car tech could hurt automotive industry
item.description: Mexico's economy ministry said in a filing with the U.S. Commerce Department the proposal could have a "substantial impact on Mexico's automotive industry. Economically, it poses potential trade barriers, disruptions to supply chains, increased production costs, and a possible risk of reduced direct and indirect employment."

item.title: ‘More than the looks, tech will be the key puller for EVs’
item.description: ETAuto spoke to Vivek Srivatsa, Chief Commercial Officer, Tata Passenger Electric Mobility Ltd. to understand the company’s strategy towards EV design and its overall transformation for a complete tech-laden approach. The company has been positioning itself at the forefront of the EV revolution, with a clear emphasis on tech-driven design.

item.title: For new-age car buyers, connected features become a driving factor
item.description: Connected cars are becoming more popular among Indian consumers, with their market share in passenger vehicles doubling since 2021. Automakers are now incorporating these features across various models, offering advanced connectivity, safety, and convenience. This trend is fueled by rising consumer demand for high-end technology in vehicles.

item.title: ACMA Mobility Foundation partners with Fraunhofer for advanced R&D in auto component industry
item.description: The ACMA Mobility Foundation has signed an MOU with Fraunhofer-Gesellschaft for R&D collaboration in India's auto component industry. This partnership aims to enhance technology, sustainability, and innovation. It involves joint projects on sustainable production and road safety. The MoU will be in effect for three years, with possible extensions.

item.title: Alphabet's Waymo closes USD 5.6 bn funding to expand autonomous ride-hailing service
item.description: Automakers and technology companies are investing in autonomous ride-hailing services to capitalize on the technology to drive commercial success, even as it faces widespread skepticism and tight regulatory scrutiny.

item.title: Chinese self-driving firm WeRide raises USD 120 mn in US IPO
item.description: The company sold 7.7 million American depositary shares in the offering at USD 15.50 a piece, the lower end of its targeted range of USD 15.50 to USD 18.50 per ADS.

item.title: Plan in the works to fund R&D for electric vehicle subsystems
item.description: "This joint call for proposal seeks to encourage a consortium approach for developing technologies. Focus is on supporting practical application of R&D in the EV value chain," Hanif Qureshi, additional secretary, ministry of heavy industries, told ET, adding that the initial fund allocation is INR 100 crore, which can be scaled up depending on the quality of proposals received.

item.title: What would you prefer a car like, a laptop/mobile, or a DVD player
item.description: "Open cars" will be like "information technology systems on wheels," continuously receiving software updates that enhance both the driving experience and on-the-go functionality. This approach offers car owners greater freedom to upgrade their vehicle's features over time, much like how we upgrade our smartphones. On the other hand, "closed cars" resemble fixed systems, akin to DVD players with region controls, limiting flexibility and locking users into predefined settings.

item.title: India right place for software defined vehicles, says PTC top official
item.description: PTC CEO Neil Barua emphasises the importance of India in the global market despite current setbacks in the automotive industry. Barua highlights PTC's focus on software-defined vehicles and its collaborations with Indian firms like Tata Motors. He underscores India's openness to global partnerships and GCCs as key advantages, alongside strategic investments in aerospace and defense sectors.

item.title: Ola Electric launches digital twin platform to transform EV manufacturing
item.description: Ola Electric has introduced the Ola Digital Twin platform to enhance its manufacturing and product development. Using NVIDIA Omniverse, Krutrim AI, and other advanced technologies, the platform enables faster equipment layout optimisation and autonomous robot training. This innovation is already improving the efficiency at Ola's Futurefactory.

item.title: Govt proposes use of AI, innovative tech to check traffic violations: Gadkari
item.description: Gadkari said road safety cannot be achieved without integrating advanced engineering solutions, enforcement of laws, and the adoption of cutting-edge technologies like AI. He said the government has decided to appoint experts from the private sector to collaborate on developing technological solutions to enhance road safety.

item.title: Hydrogen: The missing piece in India’s clean mobility revolution
item.description: In his address at the conference, Minister Hardeep Singh Puri emphasised the transformative potential of hydrogen for India’s energy landscape. “Green hydrogen requires local demand and local consumption... it will be successful in India. We still need to bring its cost of production down. The day refineries start using green hydrogen, we will be scaling it up,” said Minister Puri. His words echoed a central message from G-STIC: hydrogen is poised to become a vital component of India’s clean energy future, especially in sectors where EVs face limitations.

item.title: Jaguar Land Rover expands global innovation network; launches hub in India
item.description: Jaguar Land Rover has launched a new Open Innovation Hub in Bengaluru, India to collaborate with startups on developing advanced technologies like AI, big data, IoT, and ADAS. This initiative aims to enhance future client experiences and leverage India's growing startup ecosystem and JLR's connection with Tata Group.

item.title: India to create roadmap after achieving 20% ethanol blending target, says Hardeep Singh Puri at G-STIC conference
item.description: Shri Hardeep Singh Puri highlighted India’s efforts in sustainable energy at the 7th G-STIC Delhi Conference. He talked about hydrogen fuel technology, ethanol blending, and green hydrogen. India's energy consumption is set to rise significantly by 2030. The government's proactive approach includes advancing ethanol blending targets and exploring green hydrogen as a viable energy source.

item.title: KPIT posts 44.7% YoY PAT growth for Q2 FY25, marking 17th consecutive growth quarter
item.description: KPIT achieved USD 173 million in revenues, showing constant currency (CC) growth of 20.1% YoY and dollar revenue growth of 19.3% YoY. This growth was primarily driven by the middleware and powertrain domains, with notable contributions from the Asian market and the passenger car vertical.

item.title: Qualcomm, Alphabet team up for automotive AI; Mercedes inks chip deal
item.description: ​​Qualcomm and Google said automakers will be able to use the joint offering and Google's AI technology to create voice assistants that are unique to an automaker and can work without relying on a driver's phone.
